page.title: 14C,W. SCHOOL IN THE 1930'S
page.content: Early in the 1930's the school still belonged to the Church of England, and so each morning the rector came in for assembly. The school was opposite the church, next to the rectory. The register was marked morning and afternoo, 9a.m.and 1.30 p.m. All pupils went home for dinner at midday. Anyone arriving late for school had a black mark. Lessons were very basic; reading, writing, arithmetic etc. An inspector came periodically to inspect our work and check our progress. We sat an exam called 11 plus to decide which school we moved to, either Banbury Grammar or Byfield Elementary. The school had two classrooms and two teachers with an average of 20 pupils to each. There were two playgrounds, one for the boys and one for the girls. There were also separate cloakrooms. Toilets were out buildings at the end of each playground
